chapterTitle: Some Lessons From Capital Market History
sectionTitle: The Variability of Returns:The Second Lesson

columns.text: In this problem, we will recall the important concepts of statistics that are being used to review the trends in the market. Moreover, we will use these concepts and relate them to the second lesson of capital market history.

**a.** Variance and standard deviation are statistical measures that are used to evaluate volatility in the market.

**Variance** refers to the average of the squared difference between the actual return and the average return. **Standard deviation** on the other hand refers to the positive square root of the variance.

**b.** A normal distribution curve is characterized by a bell-shaped curve where majority of the data points are at the middle and as you move farther away from the middle (mean), lesser data points are found. 

In this type of distribution, we must remember the **Empirical Rule** which states that $99.7\%$ of the data lie between three standard deviations from the mean. Additionally, this rule also states that **68\% of the data points are found within one standard deviation from the average**.

Since the normal distribution curve is symmetrical, this means that there is a $34\%$ chance that the data point is one standard deviation away from either side of the average.

**c.** In order to solve this, we can first subtract the actual value (in this case $14.7\%$) to the average value which is $6.3\%$ then divide it by  the standard deviation.

For this, we will use $\text{x}$ to represent the event, and $\text{Z}$ to represent the Z-value which will be used to solve the probability. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}(\text{x}>14.7)&=P\left(\text{Z}>\dfrac{14.7-6.3}{8.4}\right)\\
&=\text{P}(\text{Z}>1)
\end{aligned}$$

Since our value here is $1$, it means that it is more one standard deviation away from the average. With the Empirical rule, we know that being within one standard deviation from the average is $34\%$ chance. So this means that if we are **more than one standard deviation from the average**, then the probability will be $50\%-34\%$ which is $16\%$

So the probability that you earn $14.7\%$ or more is $16\%$

For the T-bills, we will do the same formula where we subtract the actual from the average then divide the answer by the standard deviation.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}(\text{x}>14.7)&=\text{P}\left(\text{Z}>\dfrac{14.7-3.4}{3.1}\right)\\
&=\text{P}(\text{Z}>3.645)
\end{aligned}$$

Using a Z-value table, we can see that at $95\%$ confidence level, the probability of getting this return is $0.0001\%$ which is nearly improbable.

**d.** The second lesson from the capital market history is that there may be a high average annual return, but the year-to-year return may vary and there may be huge downsides. This suggests that in order to get bigger rewards, you must be ready to undertake bigger risks.
